title: How can you use active listening and subtle messaging to lead and influence your interlocutor?
first_phrase: In the previous part of the text, the author emphasizes the importance of active listening during a conversation, where the eye plays a crucial role. In the last 200 tokens, the concept of "Leading through Listening" is introduced, which involves using the technique of subtext to attract the interlocutor's thoughts. By simultaneously watching and thinking up simple messages directed at the interlocutor, one can create a psychological connection that draws them closer. This method is shown to be powerful as it puts the interlocutor at ease and makes them more receptive to concluding the deal. The text also highlights the value of good listeners over talkers in any conversation.
content: In the event that, at any given stage of the conversation, your attention were to drop, you should repeat to yourselves "it is interesting" or some other expression in that vein. Your look will then acquire the shape of an interested listener. You shall in fact learn much more about your interlocutor by paying attention to him talking that what would be the case had you been conversing about your own selves. Good listeners are, moreover, sought after more than talkers. We are even able to lead through the look alone while we are listening. Leading through listening Leading through listening: We might also, as we watch our interlocutor, think up some simple messages by using the technique of the “subtext”. Essentially, while we watch him, we are simultaneously thinking up in our mind some simple messages we are addressing at him. These messages often end up acting as "attracting magnets" of our interlocutor’s own thoughts. We may attempt to give a reasoned explanation of the way such technique functions even by relying on principles of simple psychology.
last_phrase: In summary, if you want to be a good listener and a leader through listening, it is essential to pay attention to your interlocutor by using techniques such as subtext and unconscious expressions. By doing so, you will achieve a special rapport and prestige, and your interlocutor will adopt your ideas as his own. However, keep in mind that this type of practice requires refined analytical aptitudes and the ability to adapt to individual psychological characters.
